title.narrative: Human Security Approach

description.narrative: A Human Security Approach to adress the roots causes of conflict in Mali is a four years programme (2017- 2020) funded by Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affaires. The Programme is implemented by a Consortium of three International NGOs, NCA, ICCO and HSC, with 11 implementing parners. The programme intervene in 34 communes of the regions of Mopti, Tombouctou and Gao. The interventions cover aslo Bamako at national level.

Since 2012, Mali has experienced an unprecedented socio-political crisis marked by a coup d'état and the occupation of many of its northern territory by armed groups. This crisis has negatively affected people's living conditions and exacerbated the already fragile security conditions. This situation of instability has weakened the search for ways and means to tackle the country's major development challenges, particularly those linked to the fight against poverty, and good governance.
The return to the constitutional order through the election of a new President in 2014 has contributed to laying the ground for national reconciliation, and improving the justice and the security sector. Yet, despite these positive developments, important challenges remain in the northern regions. The living conditions of the population especially the security of the population has substantially deteriorated. More importantly, there is a pressing need for inclusive mechanisms and frameworks for dialogue and reconciliation to address the root causes of the conflict.
It is within this context that ICCO Cooperation, in consortium with the Norwegian Church Aid and Human Security Collective, decided to implement a program entitled a Human Security Approach to Addressing the Root Causes of Conflict and Violence in Mali. ICCO will manage and coordinate the contract with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
ARC has defined its area of intervention which covers 34 communes (13 in Timbuktu, 11 in Gao and 10 in Mopti)

activity-description.narrative: conflict transformation (natural resources, socio-political, religious), goode governance, accountability reconciliation

title.narrative: Project image
Full sub-project - ARC implementation - ProMEva Nov 2018
Other - other
RA3.SG.3 (disaggregated) number and % of female Program beneficiaries who participate in and/or lead local peace processes

comment.narrative: It is a percentage
It is a percentage
52% of the women interviewed said they had participated in local peace processes.
It is a percentage
Overall, 46% of the women surveyed said they had participated in local peace processes, including 10% as leaders of the process.
It is a percentage
Percentage value. As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
It is a percentage
Target 2018: 41%

title.narrative: RA1.SG.4 (disaggregated) number and % of communities and civil society groups that report they have the capacity to influence formal and/or informal human security authorities.

comment.narrative: It is a percentage
93%, ie 1107 community and civil soiety groups report they have the capacity to influence formal and/or informal human security authorities.

Nearly 97% of civil society groups say they are able to influence authorities in charge of human security. -Capacity to influence refers to the perception of civil society groups on how well they feel they can lobby authorities (including advocacy and lobbying) to persuade them to make certain decisions or carry out certain activities.
Percentage value. As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Target 2018: 74%

title.narrative: Social cohesion measured through changes in Program beneficiaries’’ perceptions of other clans / ethnic groups in project area

comment.narrative: It is a percentage. To be collected at the start and the end of the program.
60% of the people surveyed (60% of women and men), believe that trust exists between the communities and the people in their localities.
66% of the individuals surveyed find this cohesion good or very good with others groups or communities.
Percentage value. As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.

title.narrative: OA.1 Number and % of Program beneficiaries who report that they see a safer/more secure future for themselves in the area where they currently live

comment.narrative: The formulation of this indicator has changed slightly from the time when the base value was collected
90344 people, 26% of the beneficiaries say they see a safer and more secure future in their region. The results by gender show 52,177 men (31%), 38,167 women (22%) and 37,484 young people (25%.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.

Only 5% of beneficiaries say they see a safer and more secure future in their region. The analysis shows that the security situation has a strong influence on this indicator, which could explain its very low level in 2020, given the deterioration of the security situation in central Mali (Mopti and Segou) and in the tri-border area (Mali- Burkina-Niger border).

The decline in the level of the indicator relative to the baseline is explained by a change in the calculation method. Indeed, a new method of calculating the indicator has been proposed MOFA after the baseline

title.narrative: RA1.SG.2 (disaggregated) number and % of conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures (e.g. peace committees, …) that are supported by the Program.

comment.narrative: It is a percentage
748 conflicts, representating 68% of conflicts identity and recorded by the Conflict Management Comitees are resolved.
It is a percentage
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
It is a percentage

Of the 183 conflicts registered, 94 were resolved, representing 51% of the conflicts handled and resolved. It should be noted that not all the conflicts handled are systematically resolved. In fact, out of the 183 conflicts listed and recorded, 129 were dealt with, of which 94 were resolved at the time of the survey.
It is a percentage
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 0% Target 2018: 46% Achieved 2018: 65% Final target (2020): 53%

title.narrative: RA3.SG.4 (disaggregated) total number of gender-sensitive policies - (#)drafted, (#)reviewed or (#)adopted - that were advocated for within the Program

comment.narrative: As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
During the year 2020, no program activity has allowed to influence the development or revision of a gender policy.
No gender sensitive policy was drafted, reviewed or adopted due to the program activities

title.narrative: Number (%) of women working on conflict resolution who do not feel discriminated

comment.narrative: 65563 (83%)women working in the field of conflict resolution say they do not feel discriminated against in their work.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 56% Target 2018: 63% Achieved 2018: 80% Final target (2020): 70%
over 84% of women working in conflict resolution say they do not feel discriminated against in their work.

title.narrative: RA1.2(disaggregated) number and % of Program beneficiaries who report they are feeling secure in the area where they live.

comment.narrative: 87,980 people (25% of beneficiairies targeted) report feelimg safe in the area they live, including 37,484 young people (25). By gender, 50,494 men (30%) and 37,486 women (22%) report feeling safe.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.

Only 4% of beneficiaries report feeling safe in their locality, compared to the planned target of 51%, an achievement rate of almost 8%. This indicator is composite, with 3 variables, namely, "personal safety of individuals", "safety of children in their localities" and "safety of their property and animals".
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 29% Target 2018: 40% Achieved 2018: 34% Final target (2020): 51%

title.narrative: RA3.1 (disaggregated) number and % of Program beneficiaries who feel that community grievances of targeted groups are effectively addressed by the government

comment.narrative: About 26% of the beneficiaries, i.e 87,221people (including 31,487 young people), believe that community grievances are being addressed by the Government. 42,920 men (25%) and 44,301 women (26%) the that community grievances are being adressed by Government.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 33% Target 2018: 43% Achieved 2018: 49% Final target (2020): 54%

title.narrative: Number of women groups that exist at the community level participating regularly and actively in dialogue platform and decision making processes by community

comment.narrative: A total of 409 women's associations/groups existing at community level in the 3 regions of intervention, i.e. 69% of the total number, regularly and actively participate in dialogue platforms and decision-making processes. The methodology to calculating this indicator is changed for 2019. Indeed, the value of 2019 is based on the groups directly support by the program, while 2018 number were based on all groups existing in the community, wheter they are directly supported or not.

A total of 500 women's associations/groups working with the ARC program at the community level in the 34 communes of intervention, i.e 79% of the total number, participate regularly and actively in dialogue platforms and decision-making processes. The 2020 target is 100%, with a 79% achievement rate.
Most of these groups operate through networks of associations (74% are networked with other groups at the local, regional or national level).
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Target 2018: 3075

title.narrative: RA1.1(disaggregated) number and % of program beneficiaries who report a reduction in the past year in the level of violent conflict in the area where they live.

comment.narrative: Approximately 45% of people, or about 153,984 individuals aged 15 and older, reported a reduction in violent conflict in their localities. This represents a 63% achievement rate of the 2020 target value.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.

Nearly 39% of people, i.e about 131,433 ipeople in the 34 communes, reported a reduction in violent conflict in their localities. Gender analysis shows 61,474 young people (41%) , 67,474 women (39%) and 63,959 men (37.4%) reporting a reduction in conflict.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 58% Target 2018: 64% Achieved 2018: 69% Final target (2020): 71%

title.narrative: RA1.SG.3 disaggregated) number and % of Program beneficiaries who report trust and cooperation within the community.

comment.narrative: 114,353, about 33% of beneficiaries reported having trust and cooperation in their communities. This translates into trust between community members and their participation in activities involving other communities. This include 47,230 youth (32%). 67,325 men (39%) and 47,028 women (27%) reported confidence and cooperation within the community.

Approximately 51% of beneficiaries reported having trust and cooperation within their communities, representing 70% achievement of the 2020 target. This translates into trust between community members and their participation in activities involving other communities.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 61% Target 2018: 67% Achieved 2018: 63% Final target (2020): 73%

title.narrative: RA3.SG.2 (disaggregated) number and % of Program beneficiaries who feel they have the ability to contribute to conflict resolution

comment.narrative: 19% of beneficiaries reported feeling represented by the government, representing a 38% achievement rate of the 2020 target. This feeling is much less present among young people (14%). This indicator is measured by people's perception of whether the government takes their interests, concerns, and values into account in actions and decisions on security and development for the benefit of communities.

220735 people, ie 64% of beneficiaries feel they have the capacity to contribute to conflict resolution, including 99,708 (67%) young people. the value of indicator is 117,819 for men (69%) and 102,916 (60%) for women.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 69% Target 2018: 74% Achieved 2018: 81% Final target (2020): 78%

title.narrative: Percentage of key observants who observe improved inclusive social contract between the local administration, civil society and citizens

comment.narrative: 174852 Key observants (50%) find that there is a better social contract between local government, civil society actors and citizens. The social contract in our context is reflected in the nature of the relationships between local governments, civil society actors and citizens. There is also their confidence in the capacity of the local administration to meet their needs, particularly in terms of security.
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 80% Target 2018: 83% Achieved 2018: 87% Final target (2020): 86%

only 22% of respondents (out of a target of 87%) feel that there is a better social contract between the local administration, civil society actors and citizens.In the context of the ARC Mali program, the best social contract between the local administration, civil society and citizens, translates into a set of things such as multiple consultations between these actors, the participation of civil society and citizens, but als

title.narrative: Number (%) of Program beneficiaries who experience increased confidence in the capacity and willingness of the state and their fellow citizens to guarantee security for all, irrespective of political or ethnic affiliation (disaggregation by sex and youth)

comment.narrative: 240,376 people, ie 70% of beneficiaries say they have confidence in the capacity and willingness of the State and their fellow citizens to guarantee security. This included 101,957 young people (69%). 127,918 men (75%) and 112,457 women (66%) were reached for the indicator.

Approximately 59% of beneficiaries claim to have confidence in the capacity of the state and the willingness of the state and their fellow citizens to guarantee security, for a target value of 86%, i.e 68% achievement of the 2020 target. This trust is reflected in the participation of the various actors concerned (civil society, State representatives and citizens) in meetings and consultations on peace and security issues, as well as the mobilization of the population by society around
As the baseline study was conducted in 2017, there are no value other than the baseline for this indicator.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 80% Target 2018: 83% Achieved 2018: 79% Final target (2020): 86%

title.narrative: Number (%) of Program beneficiairies who feel ownership of peace in local communities

comment.narrative: 242616 people (70% of the beneficiaries) claim to have personally contributed to the peace that currently prevails in their communities. This figure include 101,207 (68%) young people.
Pourcentage: Baseline (2017): 81% Target 2018: 85% Achieved 2018: 90% Final target (2020): 95%
Value at the baseline
